In your official documentation(https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/cn/manual/sharding-jdbc/configuration/config-spring-boot/), the data fragmentation + read-write separation configuration example does not set the value of default-data-source-name.
This parameter is designed to be nullable, so the doc does not set the value.
However, if this value is not set in the project, it will  Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Missing the data source name: 'null'

> It was restored because it only works with mysql and sql server and does not support postgresql. In postgresql, 116 is true and the other numbers are false.
> I think there are two ways to solve this problem:
> 
> 1. QueryResultUtil#getValueByColumnType() adds a convertType class param, which is converted directly to the correct field type here.
> 2. Provide different conversion methods according to different databases.
> 
> But both ways will make a lot of changes.

`renew()` is in OrchestrationShardingDataSource in 4.0.0.RC for updating the properties of datasource and sharding rule. Why do you want to use `renew()` of ShardingDataSource?
@liweiboy

Actually, queries with indexes should be faster thant ones without indexes. We need more tests and information to judge whether it is shardingjdbc's problem or not.
Firsty, can you compare query time on sharding tables with index and sharding tables without index? Query time on one table with index and ones without index?

Second, when you execute one query, can you get the query time that shardingjdbc uses and database uses respectively?
The file is org.apache.shardingsphere.core.optimize.statement.sharding.dml.insert.ShardingInsertOptimizedStatement.java. And the line number is 62. @tristaZero

The reason of this issue is that MySQL and Java are different in the ordering for strings.

When SQL `select code from t group by code` execute, ShardingSphere will route and rewrite to following SQL
```
select code from t_0 group by code order by code

// result 
110358011282D4
110358011282E9
110358011282h8
110358011282I0
110358011282l1
110358011282O7
110358011282P0
110358011282T4
110358011282w6

select code from t_1 group by code order by code

// result
11035801128253
110358011282f5
110358011282G1
110358011282H5
110358011282T4
110358011282U5
110358011282z1
```
As the result show, in MySQL, because you **set the COLLATE='utf8mb4_unicode_ci'**, so the lowercase is same as uppercase while sorting.
But in Java, all lowercase are larger than uppercase, for example, `110358011282f5` is large than `110358011282G1`.
And in ShardingSphere, there is one PriorityQueue to get ResultSet according to the smallest value, which caused SS can't aggregate the same value.

For SQL `select max(code) from t group by upper(code)`, the order item is `upper(code)`
the order of PriorityQueue is correct, so the result is correct.

Because sharding tables are not configured in YML or xml, but stored in mysql table.When I insert a record in the table,the sharding rule added.Then I push a message to MQ to notify my service to reinitialize.In a word,my sharding tables are not static which can be changed in my orchestration.

Remove `spring.shardingsphere.sharding.binding-tables` and retry.

You can take a look example [sharding-jdbc-example](https://github.com/apache/incubator-shardingsphere-example/tree/dev/sharding-jdbc-example/sharding-example/sharding-spring-boot-mybatis-example).
Use `application-sharding-tables.properties`

Hello, two questions.
1. I wonder if the sharding-proxy support multi-users that so i can connect the proxy using different user. As i noticed that the user & password can just set to one in the server.yaml file as following.
authentication:
  username: proxyuser
  password: *****
And it does not distinguish permissions between read and write.

2. How can i filter the source ip which forbidden to connect the proxy?  And the proxy logs doesnt include the source ip, sometimes maybe useful in troubleshooting.

##### 💛  - [Coveralls](https://coveralls.io)

> I don't think simply printing the logs in unit tests (without assertions) is a good practice. Your tests pass even when the printer prints wrong logs, which makes the tests useless.
> 
> I'd suggest mocking the `log` in class `ConfigurationPrinter` and `verify` the `log.info` method with expected parameters

You are right, and I will mock a `log` on `ConfigurationPrinterTest`.

##### 💛  - [Coveralls](https://coveralls.io)

Hi, I try to create `book` table, config with this configuration. I know this configuration has a conflict, `dataSources` only set a `ds`, but `defaultDatabaseStrategy.inline.algorithmExpression` set  `ds_${book_id % 2}` may produce two dataSources like `ds_0` `ds_1`, so I corrected this place, and everything looks right.
When I try to set multiple `dataSources`. I use Navicat to execute sql, I get a right result, but **I get a NPE** too.
This is my multiple dataSources configuration.
```yml
dataSources:

      actualDataNodes: ds_${0..1}.book_${0..1}
      tableStrategy:
        inline:
          shardingColumn: book_id
          algorithmExpression: book_${book_id % 2}
      keyGenerator:
        type: SNOWFLAKE
        column: book_id
  bindingTables:

  defaultDatabaseStrategy:
    inline:

      algorithmExpression: ds_${book_id % 2}
  defaultTableStrategy:
    none:
```

I try to track it, and I find Navicat will execute some extra sql around my actual sql for performance analysis like this.
```sql
SET PROFILING = 1;
-- my actual sql
SELECT QUERY_ID, SUM(DURATION) AS SUM_DURATION FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.PROFILING GROUP BY QUERY_ID;
```
`RoutingEngineFactory.newInstance()` will return a `DefaultDatabaseRoutingEngine` when execute `SELECT QUERY_ID, SUM(DURATION) AS SUM_DURATION FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.PROFILING GROUP BY QUERY_ID;`, but I have not set `defaultDataSourceName` in my configuration, so I get a NPE for this.
So, I think it is complex for user who just want use sharding-proxy. We must add some check for this.
What do you think ? Should sharding-proxy set a default value for `defaultDataSourceName`,  or tell user that `defaultDataSourceName` is required.

you can implement `ShardingKeyGenerator` interface to generate primary key by yourself. 
The example can see `LeafSegmentKeyGenerator`, `SnowflakeShardingKeyGenerator` or `UUIDShardingKeyGenerator`.

About the versions question, I can't answer it exactly because I don't know your environment detail.
But I suggest you use 4.0.0-RC1 first.

Hello, I have been thinking for a long time about the readonly parameter, and I cloud't found any scenario. 
1. If we use readonly for sharding, we will get many problems, such as which datasource should we use for DML or DQL, but It won't bring us any benefits.
2. If we use readonly for master-slave, I think readonly is redundant, because master must be writeable and slave must be readable.
3. If we use readonly for encrypt, I think it's redundant too.

So, I think maybe we don't need readonly parameter in sharding-sphere.

According to the JDBC specs, this setting is only a hint to the database to enable optimizations - it does not cause writes to be prohibited.
I think this parameter is needed mainly to control the default behavior of the HikariPool. Of course, it can be set to false by default.
